Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I was just about to head out for my lunch break when my phone buzzed. It was my stepbrother, his voice trembling as he told me about the news—our dad’s illness had taken a turn for the worse. He needed me, just to talk, to listen, to be there. I could hear the pain in his voice, and I knew how much he relied on me, especially since we’d promised to support each other no matter what. But as I looked up, I saw a slick, glistening puddle in the walkway—oil, maybe, or some kind of solvent. My supervisor had drilled it into us: safety first, always. If someone slipped, it would be on me. I felt my phone growing hot in my hand, my brother’s voice muffled by the roar of machines and the weight of responsibility. I was torn, heart pounding, caught between the urgent need to be a good brother and the pressing duty to keep my coworkers safe.
